physDesc.p: One page typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington c/o Miss Winifred Ellerman 1 South Audley St. London W. 1. England. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your book has come, and I think it very fine and make no doubt I can place it somewhere satisfactorily, but not, I fear, until I go to New York.

I hear from Winifred Ellerman that you are sailing on the Adriatic on the first of September. She seems to think that you are going on to California; but, from your letter to me, I presume you are going to stay a little while with your mother in Philadelphia first. Now it occurs to me that Winifred may be a little awkward to place during the visit to your mother. I should like to ask her to come to me for a week or so, but I cannot tell how I shall be, my health is so precarious. We can tell when you arrive.

I am contemplating meeting you in New York, as perhaps the services of somebody on the spot will make your landing a little easier. It depends upon my health which is rather nasty. New York is fearfully crowded, and I think it would be well for you to authorize me to engage rooms for you (or engage them yourself), which you can step into on landing, as you cannot go round from hotel to hotel looking for accommodations with a baby in tow.

Please let me know if there is anything I can do to help you. Perhaps there will be some of your family on hand to meet you, but if there is anything I can do, you may be sure that you can ask me to do it. I must see you before you go to California, at any rate. It will be such a pleasure to be with you again. I will not write any more now, for I want this letter to catch you before you sail. I do not know just when the Adriatic is due, but I will find that out. Au revoir, then, à bientôt.
body.closer: With a great deal of love from both Mrs. Russell and me, Affectionately yours,
